newsitem.title: KENYA: One dead, houses burnt in fresh Kenya violence.
newsitem.headline: One dead, houses burnt in fresh Kenya violence.

text.p: One person was killed and three houses set on fire in sporadic violence near the port city of Mombasa overnight, police said on Saturday.
Police could not say whether the incident at Mtwapa, a village 15 kms (nine miles) northeast of Mombasa, was linked to an attack three days ago when unidentified assailants killed at least 15 people.
Generally, police said the situation had returned to normal and tension had eased in and around Mombasa but a manhunt for the attackers was still underway.
Residents, however, said they still felt insecure after Wednesday night's attack -- the latest blow to the government of President Daniel arap Moi in an election year.
"The government appears incapable of restoring law and order and most people have fled from their homes," said Nyagah Murano, a resident in the Likoni area south of Mombasa.
National Police spokesman Peter Kimanthi said on Friday a major security operation, involving police, army and navy units, was underway in the area.
Reinforcements from the crack paramilitary General Service Unit were trucked into the area, which is hilly and has caves where police thought the attackers might be hiding.
Several hundred frightened local residents trekked to shelter at a Roman Catholic church compound in Likoni on Friday, carrying a few belongings on their heads.
Kimanthi said in Nairobi that six police, five attackers and two civilians were killed during Wednesday's well-organised night-long raid on police posts in Likoni.
He said a seventh policeman had died on Thursday and one more civilian had died on Friday.
"Those are the bodies we have in the mortuary. If there are other bodies in the bush we don't know about them," said Kimanthi, denying reports that any police had been abducted.
But a security officer, who declined to be identified, said at least 21 people were killed in the raid and attacks since then, and seven police including three policewomen were missing.
The security officer told Reuters that four dead civilians were found on Thursday night and two more near Likoni on Friday.
Kenya's commercial KTN television put the toll at 20 dead.
A total of 43 people have been arrested since the Likoni raid.

The search operation involving hundreds of men stretched through a tourist haven from Mombasa to the Tanzanian border, but there were no reports of casualties among the thousands of foreign tourists in the area of white coral sand beaches.
Hotel shuttle buses were suspended on Friday and tourists told to stay on hotel property until security was restored.
Scores of attackers armed with machetes seized 28 police issue G-3 rifles and two sub-machineguns on Wednesday and also burned two police posts at Likoni and freed Kenyan prisoners.
Several slogans painted on walls near Matuga pointed to a political motive exacerbated by tribal and land tensions.
"These are not criminals. These are not thugs. Federalism," said one. "Federalism. Mainlanders should go to their homes," said another. "Federalism. Justice and Land," said a third.

Moi's government has been put under pressure since May by an opposition-backed alliance demanding democratic reforms before a general election this year. Police violently breaking up rallies have rattled investors and tourists.
Kenya's central bank appealed on Friday to foreign investors not to quit East Africa's largest market after the International Monetary Fund halted a key aid package, citing corruption.
Investors pulled out of Kenya's usually lucrative weekly auction of treasury bills on Thursday because of uncertainty. The row with the IMF has hit the shilling currency and jolted investors.
